title: Quiz 1: Management Concepts & Applications
description: Test your understanding of management theories, leadership styles, functions, and resource management in nursing practice.

questions.question: Which management theory emphasizes efficiency, standardization of tasks, and the scientific selection and training of workers?
questions.explanation: Scientific Management (Classical Theory), pioneered by figures like Frederic W. Taylor, focuses on efficiency, observing worker performance (time and motion studies), and scientifically selecting and training the best workers for specific tasks.
questions.hint: Think about Frederic W. Taylor and his focus on the 'one best way' to perform a job.

questions.question: Match the following management theorists with their key contributions or theories:
questions.explanation: Taylor focused on scientific management/efficiency. Fayol identified functions (planning, etc.) and 14 principles. Weber advocated for bureaucracy. Maslow developed the hierarchy of needs. McGregor formulated Theory X and Theory Y regarding assumptions about employees.
questions.hint: Fayol is known for his 14 principles; Weber is associated with strict hierarchical structures.

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristics of a **Democratic (Participative)** leadership style?

options.text: The leader assumes full responsibility for all decisions.
Employees are encouraged to participate in decision making.
The focus is on human aspects and building effective work groups.
There is little or no visible leadership.
It leads to high morale and increased satisfaction.

questions.explanation: Democratic leadership involves group participation, focuses on human aspects/teamwork, and generally results in high morale. Assuming full responsibility is Autocratic; little visible leadership is Laissez-faire.
questions.hint: This style values the input of the team and is 'people oriented'.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the **Planning Process** in the correct logical order:
questions.explanation: The planning process mirrors the nursing process: First, you Assess the situation/problem. Second, you Set Goals/plan. Third, you Implement the plan. Finally, you Evaluate the results.
questions.hint: It follows a similar flow to the Nursing Process (ADIE).

questions.question: In a ___BLANK___ scheduling system, the chief nurse or a designate develops a master plan for the whole hospital, whereas in a ___BLANK___ system, lower-level managers (like ward in-charges) determine the schedules for their units.
questions.explanation: Centralised scheduling is done at the top level (Chief Nurse) providing an overall picture but less flexibility. Decentralised scheduling is done at the unit level, offering more control to local managers.
questions.hint: The first term relates to a central authority; the second implies delegating authority down the line.

questions.question: What is the specific management principle described as 'one person to one boss', meaning each individual should report to only one supervisor to avoid confusion?
questions.explanation: Unity of Command ensures that an employee receives orders from only one superior, preventing conflicting instructions and confusion.
questions.hint: It ensures a single line of authority for each employee.

questions.question: Review the budget table below. Which section represents a **Capital Budget** item?

richContent.content:
SectionItem DescriptionCost (Kshs)
APatient Fees (Revenue)300,000
B1Food & Drugs (Recurrent)200,000
B2Purchase of Suction Machine100,000
B3Linen & Uniforms20,000

questions.explanation: Capital Budget items involve major equipment or physical changes requiring large sums of money and having a long lifespan (e.g., > 1 year). The 'Purchase of Suction Machine' (Section B2) fits this definition. Food, drugs, and linen are recurrent operational expenses.
questions.hint: Look for a major equipment purchase rather than daily consumables or income.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized **methods of nursing care delivery**?
questions.explanation: The four main methods of patient assignment/care delivery are: Case Assignment, Functional Nursing, Team Nursing, and Primary Nursing. 'Bureaucratic Nursing' is not a standard care delivery model.
questions.hint: Think about how patients are assigned to nurses (by task, by team, or one-to-one).

questions.question: According to the principle of **delegation**, a nurse manager should delegate sensitive issues such as staff disciplinary actions to subordinate staff to foster their leadership development.
questions.explanation: False. As a general guideline, only routine activities should be delegated. Sensitive issues, such as disciplinary actions and staff performance appraisals, should NOT be delegated by the manager.
questions.hint: Consider the confidential and authoritative nature of disciplinary actions.

questions.question: Read the scenario below. Which stage of the **Change Process** (Kurt Lewin) is the manager addressing?

richContent.content: Scenario: A nurse manager wants to introduce a new computerized documentation system. Before installing the computers, she holds several staff meetings to discuss why the current paper system is inefficient and how the new system will save time. She encourages staff to voice their fears and explains the benefits to convince them that change is necessary.

questions.explanation: The 'Unfreezing' stage involves getting rid of existing practices and ideas that stand in the way of change. It requires high-level communication to convince employees that change is necessary and to overcome resistance before the actual change is implemented.
questions.hint: This stage is about preparing people for change by 'melting' their resistance.
